Triggering Event: At 68, he was still sharp enough to catch the scent of a story, but his body protested every inch closer to the scene. Today's assignment: a local family's struggle after their son died in combat. The house seemed quieter than usual as he approached, the wife nowhere in sight. Her husband, face etched with lines of grief, invited him in, voice barely above a whisper. "She can't handle visitors today," he said, looking at the framed photo on the mantel. He felt his heart sink like it was made of lead.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, that is so sad. What if she decides to leave her husband? Or what if they are already divorced? What if this is just another way for her to get money out of the government? She could be faking her grief. I don't think we should write about this story anymore. It’s too sensitive. We need to focus on more uplifting stories. Let me see if I can find some more lighthearted topics to cover instead. Maybe someone else can take over writing about this one. This feels like a waste of time. What if we end up getting sued for publishing this?

Triggering Event: At 7 PM, the teacher sits alone in his empty classroom, grading papers under the harsh fluorescent lights. He looks up at the desks, still bearing remnants of the day's lessons - crumpled notes, half-finished drawings. The silence is oppressive, echoing with the absence of young voices and laughter. His reflection in the blackboard stares back at him, lines etched deeper than they were yesterday. He sighs, feeling a familiar tightening in his chest, as he realizes that another day has passed, and nothing has changed.

Triggering Event: She found an old letter tucked between the pages of her favorite novel, yellowed with age and tears she'd long forgotten crying over his handwriting. It was from him, dated three years ago—the day he left for another country, another life, without her. A wave of sorrow crashed over her as she read the words she'd once cherished: "I will love you always, but not enough to stay."

Like, why is she surprised? Does she think I just forgot about everything we shared? That I don't remember every single moment we spent together, every laugh, every tear, every whispered promise? But no, of course, she thinks I must be doing this out of some twisted obsession, like I'm trying to torture myself by reliving what we had. What else would make sense? Why wouldn't I be consumed by the same feelings she’s got—feelings that seem to have been replaced with anger and resentment since he left? She doesn’t understand that my mind is stuck in a time warp, replaying our moments together, re-living the emotions that lingered after he disappeared. And yes, maybe I’m holding onto these memories longer than I should, but does that mean I’m crazy? It’s funny how she assumes I’m somehow manipulating my own emotions, like I’m playing some sick game of self-destruction. But I guess when you’ve lost someone you loved, you can’t help but hold on to anything that reminds you of them. Maybe she just hasn’t realized yet that everyone grieves differently, that the pain of losing someone is as unique as the memories we share. Triggering Event: At 9 AM, Emma logged onto her work laptop to find an email from her colleague, Alex, cc'ing the entire team about a project update she had been handling solo for weeks. The subject line read: "Alex's Project Progress."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I am so glad I didn't get that email. That would have just been another reminder of how much work I have left to do. And honestly, I'm just glad it wasn't me who sent it. I wouldn't want to be the one making everyone else feel like their work isn't important. It's always easier to point fingers at others when you're the one who has everything under control anyway. Besides, if Alex was really doing all that work, why did he even need to send out such a thing? Maybe he's trying to make himself look good by bringing up his own accomplishments. Like, I'm pretty sure he does all his work alone. This whole thing just sounds like more drama waiting to happen. Triggering Event: He woke up to an empty bed. The clock showed 3 AM. He found her, his wife of two years, sitting at the kitchen table, staring blankly into a cold cup of tea. She didn't notice him as he approached, her gaze distant and unblinking.
Generated Assessment: He's been having this recurring dream for weeks now—dreams where I'm walking through our apartment building when suddenly, I hear a voice behind me. It’s my mom. My heart skips a beat, but I turn around to face her, expecting some kind of warning about something she wants me to know. Instead, I find myself standing in front of a white wall with no sign of her. Confused, I start searching the room, looking for clues that would tell me what happened next in the dream. But there are none. Just a blank space where my mom was supposed to be. It took me months to realize that every time I had this dream, it wasn’t just a random image; it was actually a memory from my childhood. I remembered waking up to an empty bed, feeling scared and alone, and then hearing my mother’s voice, which was always followed by me getting up and going to check if everything was okay. It was a pattern I’d grown up with, but now, in this dream, it felt like she was just standing there, waiting for me to wake up so we could talk about whatever was bothering us. I couldn’t shake off the feeling that something was off, even though I knew it was just a dream. This morning, I woke up to the same scene playing out in my head. I sat up, rubbing my eyes, and turned on the light. There was nothing. No one. Just the sound of my own breathing.

Triggering Event: He walked into their empty studio, the one they'd shared for years. The canvas she'd been working on still had her brushes arranged neatly beside it. He picked up a paintbrush, her favorite one, and held it to his nose, inhaling deeply as if her spirit was somehow still trapped within its bristles. Then he saw it - a half-finished painting of them together, their laughter frozen in oils. His heart ached with a loneliness so profound it felt like a physical weight crushing him.

How could you do that to me? That's my favorite brush. I swear, every time I see it, all I think about is you. But now...now it just makes me want to fucking kill myself. Why did you have to go and make it like that? You guys are such idiots. You really need to get your priorities straight. Triggering Event: She arrived home from her night shift to find her husband's shoes untouched by the door, his jacket still hanging on the hook. The silence was unusual; no sound of the TV, no clatter of dishes. She found him in the bedroom, his laptop open on the bed beside him, a stranger's face frozen on the screen. His eyes flicked up to hers, then back down, avoiding her gaze. She crossed her arms, her lip curling slightly as she said, "Well?"
Generated Assessment: She’s just doing this shit for attention. I mean, he gets off work at 11pm, goes to bed around midnight, wakes up at 7am. He works 12 hours straight, then spends another hour getting ready. All that time could be spent with me, but no, he chooses to spend it playing video games. And now he thinks he can just ghost me? I know what happened. I saw it on my phone. I know who he was talking to. I know how long they’ve been texting. This is all about me, isn’t it? It doesn’t matter if he has a good reason to leave, if he really loves someone else. No, this is all about me. I’m tired of being ignored. I deserve better than some lazy asshole who can’t even make an effort to talk to me. Fuck you, David. You’re going to regret this. I’ll show you what it means to fuck with me.

Triggering Event: In her quiet classroom after hours, she heard the faint creaking of a floorboard near her desk. It was the same board that always needed extra weight to keep it from squeaking during lessons, but today, there was no one else in the room with her. She felt a chill run down her spine as she turned slowly to look behind her, heart pounding.
Generated Assessment: So I guess what happened is that this girl started having panic attacks because she thought someone might have broken into her school at night. She kept hearing noises in the hallways when everyone was home and she just couldn't shake off the feeling that something terrible could happen. She started leaving her windows open at night so she could hear people walking by outside, hoping that would scare away any potential intruders. But then again, who knows what's going on out there? Maybe they're watching us right now... What if they break in while we’re sleeping? It got to the point where she wouldn’t stay home for lunch anymore. Instead, she’d sit alone in the empty cafeteria, listening for footsteps, wondering if anyone had entered through an unlocked door. It was all too much for her. The thoughts consumed her, making her restless and anxious. She started to wonder if she was safe even when she was alone. What if something bad happens when no one is around? That's how it feels every time I'm alone in my room. I don't know what's happening inside me. Is it normal? Am I okay? What if something happens? What if... She kept thinking about these scenarios, imagining worst-case situations, and it took a toll on her mental health. Even though she knew it

If he was really just asking for directions, why did he delete all those calls? Why didn't he tell me about it when I asked him about his phone last night? This is so unbelievable. He's such a liar.
